Sorry to bring in controversy here, but Mr Siliacus...
You may want to rese=
arch the name Gordon Robson before you make such
rude and obnoxious stateme=
nts.
Also, I have yet to find a traditional togishi that will advise people=

to use lemon juice on a blade (or even confidently call themselves a
togis=
hi when not trained in Japan)
Sorry, but there are ways to reply to people =
in a civil manner, and
that isn't it.
If this were my forum, you would be a=
n ex-member.

Brian

> > Patrik,
> > Agreed the wood =
graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of that
> > sort
> > of work=
 I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of Japanese
> > workmans=
hip, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish where the
> > metal
> =
> edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the handle
> =
> butts
> > up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to the habak=
i
indicates
> > poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the proof of th=
e
pudding for
> > the
> > blade will be when you take the handle off and se=
e the tang. Do this -
> > remove the habaki and take good closeup photos of=
 both sides of
the tang
> > and
> > put them up. The blade is the typical s=
hape of a Meiji tourist
piece, but
> > running through the images again I'm=
 of the opinion that the
koshirae is
> > modern as it just does not have th=
e refinement of shape that we
expect to
> > see in Japanese workmanship. So=
 the blade may be old, but if it
does not
> > have a clear and distinguisha=
ble hamon it is nonetheless a "junk"
piece.
